review_title: My mental health has suffered while working here but it pays bills.
job_title: Building Service Worker in Normal, IL
pros: Don't expect a thank you or a lot of training. Expect to cover people's areas when they are gone a lot. Nepotism was an issue a few years ago but now they act like nepotism isn't a big deal and they make bosses work above or below their family members. Start out at 15 an hour with no bonus or anything. It will take you a year and a half to get up to just under 19 an hour, and 4 years before you're at top pay at like 21. They pay you pennies and charge 119 for parking each year. Parking is terrible and your mental health will suffer. Good insurance and somewhat good benefits. That will keep you feeling stuck here. Expect no raises after 4 years expect for the occasional 30 cents once a year maybe. Do yourself a favor and go into a trade or a job that is paying more than 20 an hour.
cons: All they care about is diversity and inclusion and making money. Upper management is the reason this place is falling apart. All they care about is hiring diversity hires.

pros: Good benefits, professional development opportunities. Bloomington Normal is a nice place to live. Campus is clean, safe and nice
cons: Some facilities on campus are in need of updating, but this is happening slowly.

pros: They allowed for a flexible schedule with school.

pros: Nice environment, the supervisors were amazing

review_title: Low Pay, Abusive Work Culture, No Opportunities for Advancement
job_title: Residence Hall Coordinator in Bloomington, IL
pros: There aren’t any…genuinely one of the worst experiences of my life, I was bullied, and expected to work 60+ hours a week as a salaried employee.
cons: Literally all of it. Don’t work here unless there are some major cultural changes. You will be made to feel worthless and never ever recognized for hard work unless you are a loudly straight, white, cis male, and even then, if you seem vulnerable, your ideas will be stolen, credited to someone else on purpose to make you feel bad, and your supervisor will blame you for things that are their fault. I was once told that I wasn’t getting recognition for my work because the department could not retain supervisors in my area. I was blamed for this because “you don’t really have a mentor who has been here long term and can advocate for you.” I was then fired after being extremely depressed and anxious about my (lack of) professional and after I fell very behind at work because my graduate assistant quit with no notice and was never replaced. The sheer amount of trauma and abuse I endured have resulted in intense weekly therapy and I am so mentally ill that I have been unable to work for nearly 2 years. DO. NOT. WORK. HERE. (At least not for Housing, unless you want to be in years of therapy for trauma/abuse like I have been)

review_title: Great place, good people & opportunities, nice campus
pros:
-Nice campus
-Academia in the Midwest - down to earth, helpful, warm people
-Good size campus in lower key suburban type community.
-Very easy weekend jaunts which are common among residents to Chicago, St Louis, and Indianapolis with several interstate directions connecting here. 
-Nice smaller airports nearby including a very pleasant facility in town, plus Chicago O'Hare is easy to get to a couple hours away.
-This is the kind of place where if you accidentally leave your front door unlocked overnight here and there, you’ll very likely be fine and feel pretty safe which is worth a lot in small city kind of place.
cons:
-Parking can be great and it can be annoying. If you are running a bit behind and it’s an icy frigid day, hope you find an easy in and out place to park not far from your destination. Plus, ticketing is abundant and has been for years if you overstay even a very short time at meters to finish up class if adjunct and not teaching enough to have a permanent space. 
-The area is more mellow, sleepy and peaceful than vibrant with lots of options if you are outdoorsy wanting a lot of variety, a foodie who loves lots of different types of options, or rely on a busy nightlife.
-It’s a pretty rural area of the Midwest, so you won’t have a ton of variety in activities or a slew of outdoor and indoor event options every weekend within a few miles in any direction compared to more metro areas, but events that do happen have a lot of involvement, participation, and community pride which is part of Midwestern charm.

review_title: ISU can do better, but refuses
pros:
There are some truly good, strong, and supportive faculty at ISU. They want the best for their co-workers, staff members, and administrators who work long hours to keep everything going. The sprinkling of incredibly kind and thoughtful people at ISU is the best it has to offer.

The grounds workers and building service workers do great work to keep everything beautiful and clean. One of the reasons I felt at home when I first started at ISU was that I felt my direct supervisors were working just as hard as me, and cared just as much as me. That is rare, as is the ability to find people who can speak honestly about the good and the bad, and there are people at ISU who are able to do that. There are caring students who write thank-you notes for the time you spend with them and students who work and go to school full time, they are tremendous. 

There are pockets of goodness, however the longer you work at ISU the more evident it becomes that there are many choices being made that are not for the greater good of anyone but people who knew how to kiss the right ring and get paid obscenely for it.

If you can find the time and energy, you can get more degrees/education as an incentive. I was able to use my tuition waiver benefit at a reciprocal state university with a stronger name recognition and that has been helpful. You are taxed on any tuition overage if you incur more than $5,250 in courses per year, though.
cons:
The prevailing culture in higher education is to make decisions entirely surrounding profit, even at a state-funded university. ISU is no different, though they and other universities love to say they are different. They claim to be a great working climate. They claim to care about diversity, equity, and inclusion for students, faculty, and staff. They claim to care about a lot of things. The words and actions simply do not match: there are profit-gobbling Republicans holding the strings at ISU and it's evident. They don't truly care about any of the things I mentioned.

 Human Resources is run by poisonous scabs who somehow fail upwards into huge salaries while there are staff members and graduate students working full time who still qualify for food stamps. ISU's handling of COVID response has been weak and not at all inclusive of safety. They crafted a WFH policy but deny every medical and non-medical accommodation request. The new president is more of the same purse-clenching Republicanism as the last guy, and what's worse is her background is in biomedical science and the COVID management is two steps above abysmal. We haven't had a progressive president in 8 years. There are people on the board of trustees who think that online instruction is useless and that POC are best seen as tokens of diversity. It feels like a nightmare. 

The only reward for doing a good job is to get more work, and faculty who claim to care about social justice treat staff like servants.

Failing upwards is a shocking phenomenon that happens in work cultures all over the world, there is no escaping it. But it happens so regularly at ISU that it colors the daily experience of working there and creates a bitter working environment. People who fail upwards even after proving time and time again that they were not even capable of doing the job they came from just make more work for everyone else who DOES care and DOES want to do good work.

Additionally, ISU has been consolidating staff jobs over the last 5 years so that each job posting is an amalgamation of what used to be 3-5 individual jobs. The workload is impossible and that is why people who don't care get nothing done and people who DO care are worked and stressed to the bone with no incentives for doing so. HR has consistently denied the union attempts to push to $15/hour minimum wage when food service and retail are making their way more quickly to that end. ISU also requires bachelor's and master's degrees for office support and specialized staff jobs, which means that with no consideration of wages, the degrees become valueless. They have minimized the child-tuition benefit to the point where you have to be working there for five years to utilize it.

I understand there are no perfect companies or universities, there are always going to be gaps in equity, support, and appreciation. I admit that it is time to leave ISU and that is likely coloring much of my review, however it makes me more angry because higher education is an environment that knows better and refuses to DO better. They are the ideological centers of education, that ideology is capable of being implemented in so many ways, even with state funding considerations. Knowing better and doing worse is a greater condemnation than not knowing and making terrible decisions.

review_title: ISU Office Staff and the Curse of the Classist Microagression
pros:
Great insurance (if the state of Illinois doesn't decide to take it away);
Lots of paid time off, for example almost two whole weeks off for winter break without having to dig into your accrued time off is great!
cons: If you're not a Ph.D. or a student, your knowledge, skills, and abilities (and most of all, your opinions) mean nothing. I'm sure there are a few pockets where the occasional department doesn't discriminate against its support staff, but I haven't found one yet. Most academic departments do not see office staff as even being a part of the department. Faculty here like to stand around talking about microaggressions day in and day out, yet somehow they never seem to notice when they commit classist microaggressions against staff. Also, Normal is such an expensive place to live, many support staff can't afford to live here but instead commute from smaller towns in the surrounding area. Personally, I always have to have at least one part-time job to supplement my full-time income at ISU, and it is not uncommon for me to have to rely on local food pantries to feed myself and one child. You have to either be single with no one to support but yourself or have a spouse with a much better job than you in order for the pay here to be considered anywhere near a living wage.

pros: Great place with good benefits
cons: Limitation to move up in position

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Normal, IL
pros: generous tuition waiver for graduate assistants
cons: not that I know of

pros: Friendly staff and good working environment.
cons: Workload might increase during end semester.

pros: Great place to work always
cons: No bad things to say

pros: Very welcoming environment, always willing to help each other out.

pros: Great working environment for you

pros: Flexible Schedule, Fair pay, and a great experience.

review_title: Best job on campus for students
job_title: Student Operations Manager in Bloomington, IL
pros: Work around your schedule well
cons: Will always want to work so won’t have free time

pros:
-Flexible Scheduling
-Great opportunities for promotion
cons:
-Sometimes not great professional development
-Not great pay

review_title: Supervising student employees through the facility
pros: Awesome team environment for work
cons: Can't think of anything at the moment!

review_title: Illinois State University - Great Vacation Benefits - Low Salaries
pros:
- Vacation Benefits ( about a month a year and can accrue up to 90 days )
- Christmas Shutdown ( university shutdown over Christmas break for 7 days )
- Pension
- Free Education 
- Work life Balance is good.
cons:
- Salaries are lower that competitors in Central Illinois.
- Salaries are public listed and are not private.
- Salaries are tied to State of Illinois budget.  Due to the State budget being in red usually increases are extremely minimal
- Alot of Change.  Areas in university are constantly being reorganized or merged so there is feeling of being on a rollercoaster constantly.
- No clear promotion or advancement.

job_title: Social Media Director in Normal, IL
pros: It was a great experience and I learned a lot.
cons: I have nothing bad to report at all.

pros: I had flexible work hours
cons: off campus housing created long walks to work

pros: Helped pay for my master's degree, provided lots of experience in research, admin work, etc.
cons: Hard to manage work-life balance.

pros: Best job I have had, perfect work life balance and great work environment
cons: not many that I can think of

pros: Quality institution to work at in the glass and metal wood program
cons: None to speak of truly

review_title: An okay university that could be great if it seriously tried
job_title: Director of Development in Normal, IL
pros: Pay and benefits are excellent. Like most academic environments, you're working with smart folks who (for the most part) care about making a difference in students' lives. Professional staff are generally allowed to manage their own time and achieve work/life balance. Plenty to do and get involved in (culturally and professionally) on campus. The campus is beautiful and a lot of improvements are underway. You can walk to a lot of new shops and restaurants in the renovated 'Uptown' Normal. Bloomington-Normal is an above average community in many ways -- driven by the presence of State Farm's corporate headquarters. Lots of shopping, restaurants, etc.
cons: Like most academic environments, there's plenty of self-serving bureaucracy to go around. Some professional staff completely miss the point that STUDENTS are the entire reason the University exists and education is the core mission. Everything else is secondary to that. REAL change doesn't seem to get addressed and there's a certain complacency with being mediocre (but a lot of talk about being great.) Trustees either don't want to know or don't have the sophistication to distinguish talk from from real action. You are either in or out with senior administration, meaning HARD questions don't get asked for fear of retribution. Once you're out you will literally be out.

pros: Excellent experience in my field, opportunities to help others.
cons: Very limited hours, limited pay.

pros: Flexible, growing, and good experience
cons: lack of communication and feedback

pros: The Teaching schedule is flexible
cons: The pay and faculty support is terrible

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Normal, IL
pros: Good benefits and culture of learning
cons: State budget has negatively impacted raises.

pros: Learning opportunities when translating classes
cons: Low wage and sometime inconsistent hours

pros: Meal provided before or after a 4 hour managerial work shift / Relatively easy to trade shifts, pick up shifts, or find a substitute for your shift / If competent and put out fires as they rise, shifts can be be of ease / Great co-workers, administration, and subordinates
cons: Astonishing levels of incompetency from both costumers as well as subordinates / Must take an appropriate amount of time to train every employee on shift otherwise you will have subjected yourself to their duties every shift (more of a tip) / Stuck with employees when they should have been fired (or in some cases not even hired) / Understaffed resulting in extremely hectic shifts and holiday weekend shifts resulting in four hour shifts of unbelievable boredom

review_title: A Great Place to Work, Salaries fairly stagnent
job_title: Director, Technology Services in Normal, IL
pros: A great place to work with very good benefits.  Administration is very supportive and most positions including mine have a great deal of latitude on methods.  Opportunities to be innovative and customer service excellence is well recognized.  Working conditions are usually very good.  Real opportunities to shine
cons: The negatives are really due to State funding decreases.  Salaries are relatively stagnent and are not reflective of performance.  Last five years have seen salary increases of about 2 percent per year, with little varience for performance.  You have to change jobs to get that recognition.  Also the choices are a basic 401K with good contributions, but you have to invest extra to retire, or a very good State pension system where the plan is 80 percent underfunded and subject to constant threats of reform/cuts/default.

pros:
-School comes first so getting time off is/was easy.
-Worked around my schedule.
-Allowed time off during finals or project deadlines for classes
-Easy work. They expect students to not have experience but I had years of actual job experience.
-Summer/weekends off.
-Studied during downtime (depends on where you work)
-Friendly coworkers. Really casual environment.
-Dress code is casual for student workers or business casual for interns.
-Low stress.
-Management very easy to talk to and understanding.
cons:
-Low pay. Min wage for students, higher for interns/grad assistants but nothing livable.
-State funding might restrict how much you can work if you want more hours. Not ISU's fault, just a heads up.

pros: Illinois State is a great place to work with endless potential.  As a state job, you get many of the perks that most state jobs provide (medical, dental, life).  The work/life balance is really commendable at Illinois State University.  The upper management in most of the departments is definitely willing to give their employees some much needed time off.  Since it is a university, there are constantly top talent being drawn towards positions at Illinois State, creating a diverse, articulate, and capable work force.
cons: Illinois State is in Normal, IL, which is a wonderful small midwestern town.  However, many people who are from Chicago originally do not appreciate the slower pace.

pros:
Tuition paid, fun employees, easy work, skills to put on resume, "student first, worker second" attitude, decent pay rate. 

Always had an easy time asking for days off due to finals or group meetings. Loved my boss and the department a lot, was rehired for the next semester.

Mostly depends where you work. Some grad assistants sit in an office for hours doing homework, others do actual work for a department. Unless you have a job lined up, I suggest getting the actual work GA positions.
cons: Hours are capped, some grad assistants do busy work or paper work for profs. GAs that grade and help teach really get the short end of the stick and get stupid questions from undergrads.

pros: The College of Education has a wonderful mission to educate teachers to teach all children in Illinois.  The College has historically been nationally recognized and has received many accolades.
cons: There has been an overall change of leadership in the College since 2012.  The current leadership team is very hierarchical and punitive.  They meet behind closed doors, do not allow for substantive input from faculty or staff and generally treat employees extremely poorly, with little concern for their personal welfare.  The new leaders in the College are widely perceived as micromanagers more concerned with controlling employees than with responding to the new challenges of teacher education.

pros: Well-managed school. They are well-organized. ISU is a very good school. It's easy to apply for graduate assistantships. Can't speak for employment in the undergraduate programs, but the graduate programs seem to be on top of things when it comes to employment and treating their student workers fairly.
cons:
Sometimes certain processes can be slow- grad assistantship HR isn't always quick to reply or finish tasks, it seems, but overall they do a really good job. 
The location is far from Chicago and the suburbs. But that's not relevant for everyone.

review_title: A place to explore the broad roles of your profession, while still getting big corporation benefits
job_title: Director of Technology in Normal, IL
pros: Flexibility to work across areas, with the benefits of a much larger company
cons: Advancement is limited by your educational degree which is true at all Universities.  There is only so far you can advance without a Masters degree and then to go higher a Ph.D and teaching experience

review_title: It was a good experience as a graduate student job
pros: It was a really good experience for me to work at ISU as a graduate assistant. It pays good enough to have a student life in a city like Normal which costs of life is not too much. I did not have to pay my tuition as well which was good. I also learned many things while I was working as a research assistant.
cons: you may find Normal/IL very boring small town. The weather is also tough! winters are so cold and summers are freaking hot and humid.

review_title: Very limited opportunity within Administrative Technologies
pros: The medical/dental/vacation benefits are the best pros for ISU.  If you are hired as a civil service, there are also retirement options that may be beneficial (assuming the state stays solvent, which is not a certainty).  Its also a wonderful diverse tolerant community.  Working with students is always dynamic and exciting.  ISU is also in good fiscal health compared to other universities.
cons: Within Administrative Technologies there are a number of issues:  1. The movement away from hiring people with a civil service classification (which makes it difficult to get laid off) to one/two year contracts.  You take much less pay working for ISU, the typical tradeoff use to be job security, that is now changing.  2. Lack of clear upward advancement -- Many people keep the same job duties forever.  There is almost no potential for advancement.  Hand in hand with this is no way to move up in salary.  If you are taking a job at ISU, make sure your starting salary meets your future needs, you will not have anything more than a 1% to 3% raise, depending on the health of the university.  3. Enterprise mentality - In the last two years, there has been a movement towards treating people as they were working within a large enterprise.  This has meant mandatory overtime for large numbers of IT staff.  So be prepared to be asked to work evenings, weekends, and have blackout/brownout periods which limit your ability to take time off.  4. Poor morale - As for Fall of 2014, morale is poor within Administrative Technologies and most competent people that are not tied into the civil service retirement are leaving.  Administrative Technologies has had about 40% turnover in the last 2 years. 5. Politics - Every job has office politics.  The issue with ISU is that there is no bottom line, so it is very easy to make decisions based on friendships, instead of ability

pros:
-Give great introductory training
-There are many resources available to help TAs and professors are always willing to help
-Professors are very supportive overall and general work environment is very pleasant
-TAs have a fair amount flexibility in labs and professors take feedback seriously
-TAs are given a large amount of responsibility with limited hand-holding (Be Prepared to utilize teaching skills)
       -Great Teaching Experience
cons:
-Implementation of changes to labs may vary depending
-Students may not always be enthusiastic about labs
-TAs are given a large amount of responsibility (Be prepared to Teach)

pros: Great atmosphere and environment full of hard working individuals.  The faculty, staff, and students are committed to excellence and success.  During my time there I was happy with the management, pay and overall sense of community.
cons: Communication between department to department can be inconsistent at times.  Though most issues were rectified quickly, the inconsistency can be a bother at times.

review_title: A great experience as a tutor
pros: Everyone worked together in a communicative manner that helped develop a wonderful workplace.  Each day was a pleasure to work with my coworkers.  They were all very friendly and helpful.
cons: Sometimes would be sitting around with nothing to work on.  There was no real ways to advance due to the job being designed for a part-time working student.  It felt that management was out of touch with how we operated.

review_title: A friendly place where you can enhance you professional as well as interpersonal, social skills
pros: This organization has amazing opportunities for graduate students. Great pay, tuition waiver and amazing experience that you can't find anywhere else
cons: Professors, i worked with, are world class so you need to keep up with strict deadlines. In winter, the place is a little bit cold but other than that it's an amazing place to study, work and build you life.

review_title: Student Activities & Involvement Student Worker/Front Desk/Secretary
pros: As a student worker there is a lot of free time to do hw! Bosses are so friendly and understanding.  It's a nice way to get money and experience while also treating it as a study hall.
cons: There isn't much to do.  You're only there to answer phone calls and assist students who come into the office which rarely happens.  Sometimes your boss will give you something to do if you tell them you're bored.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Normal, IL
pros: Illinois State is a wonderful academic institution. This is my second graduate assistantship - the first was with the Department of Psychology, and the second was with the Chicago Teacher Education Pipeline. Both jobs were very positive experiences that helped finance my education, and my advisers helped to prepare me for a future in analytics.
cons: For my current position with the Chicago Teacher Education Pipeline, the analyses we do are not very complex. Although it has helped refine my basic statistical knowledge, I would rather the experience be with more complicated research designs.

review_title: Enriching experience combined with meeting excellent people.
job_title: Student IT Technician in Normal, IL
pros:
Great benefits compared to most employment opportunities.  
Most people you work with are great, and because the teams are usually small, you get very close.
cons:
In turn for great benefits, pay is usually less than the average for that job.
IT Management is poor at making decisions for the long term, and thus have caused many developers to seek employment elsewhere.

pros: Division I athletics program, discount on education for master's degree, besides football they have excellent facilities, nice area to live in. The school itself is excellent, but the Athletics Department is not run well.
cons: Poor management in marketing that does not allow for creativity. Nepatism shown in job hirings with personnel who do not have enough experience and need training from their subordinates. Poor pay and benefits.

pros: A supportive staff and excellent training. First set of students to pick their classes and schedules. Lots of resources, and free room and board.
cons: It's clear that in order to take hold of the RA position, you have to know some people within that department/group to get in. Candidates who have relationships with current RAs or RHCs or even the front desk managers tend to be picked more than a candidate who doesn't have that connection (though they have to work extra hard to stand out)

pros: Being a research assistant was a great experience which paid for my graduate school at ISU.  This job has given me a lot of opportunities that wouldn't have been available if I did not take it.
cons: You are assigned a random teacher to work under each semester and depending on who you are assigned, it may be very unorganized or overwhelming.  The pay is not great but I think benefits outweigh this issue

review_title: Ok if you are only need to work 1 job.
job_title: Instructional Assistant Professor in Bloomington, IL
pros: Many teaching options to choose from, labs, clinical, classroom and online. Good for those who have a lot of extra time to devote.
cons: Poor orientation process for part time faculty. Not everyone has a lot of free time to access University email , online electronic classroom. Need more support from course leaders.

review_title: Good place to work, but a bit insulated
pros: Lots of nice people; chance to help students in their futures and help develop the next generation. Good benefits.
cons: Parking is very difficult on campus. And the people tend to be isolated in the sense that outsiders often have a hard time overcoming their status as outsiders. There is a definite preference to go with folks who are "local" to ISU.

review_title: Good university environment, but lacks communication
pros: Good work environment, usually nice people, tasks are easy to accomplish.
cons: One of the biggest problems in this university is the lack of communication between departments and between employers and employees. Also, some internal processes are overly complicated and too bureaucratic. This is probably due to it being a state university. Last but not least, the pay is a little low, and this is particularly critical for international students.

pros: Everyone was so kind and welcoming, I worked in many departments throughout the library and University. I will say that they are very committed to their motto. They work hard to be diverse and always put the students first but don't forget about the staff.
cons:
Location- It's a college town, there's not much more to say. 
Advancement can also be hard as they rarely hire in house for many positions.

pros: I was hired as a student worker at the Technology Support Center and it was a great experience for me! I got a look first hand at what the full-time job would be like and had regular employer reviews which always helped me gauge where I was. Everyone is super friendly and you get great schedule flexibility!
cons: I don't really have much to complain about!

review_title: Illinois State is an awesome employer.
pros: Work schedule is very flexible. The professors I worked with are very professional, supportive, understanding and helpful. The benefits I get from work helped me a lot in supporting my studies at the University. Workload is very much manageable.
cons: Minimal professional growth. The sole purpose of the job is to support my studies financially so there is not much of an opportunity to grow professionally.

review_title: If you find a position you like, the overall experience is pleasant, simple, and convenient.
pros:
Flexible schedule
Freedom to work at your own pace
Trusted to do your best work and enter your work hours
Build rapport with your employer (teachers, administrators...)
Helpful peers
cons:
With much freedom comes a lack of direction (if you're self-motivated and don't have a problem with creating work for yourself, this shouldn't be an issue)
Insufficient source of professional experience

job_title: Student IT Technician in Normal, IL
pros: The position gives you a lot of insight into the behind the scenes operations of the University. Flexible work schedule works around your classes and any tests/homework you need to catch up on.
cons: Professional development is minimal in the position. The workload is more than the size of the staff can handle, so at times it feels like you're fighting just to not move further behind.

review_title: I worked as a student librarian; it was fun and I learned a lot.
pros: The full time employees were always so kind to me and helpful whenever I had questions. I really grew as a person at Milner Library.
cons: Honestly, only real con I can think of is that the pay is minimum wage. However it's a student position so that was not surprising.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant & Tutor in Normal, IL
pros: Solid pay check and good work environment, people were always friendly and it was made clear your responsibilities
cons: There really weren't any except you can always get paid more, even more so when you are a student

job_title: Bsc Student Manager in Normal, IL
pros: Conviently located for working students, highest possible salary for student workers, amd enjoyable coworkers.
cons: Repetitive tasks, some micromanaging, and youre only provided one polo for you uniform even though its a lot of manual labor.

pros: Overall a good place to work.
cons: Parking is expensive.  Dental insurance is practically useless since the provider isn't more than a year behind in paying, meaning no dentist will take it.

pros:
Flexible Hours
Excellent Work Environment
Management Invested in Worker Happiness
cons: Occasionally, there is a lack of perceived discipline amongst the other student workers.. which isn't necessarily a bad thing, flexibility in disciplinary action relative to the individual can be positive for all

review_title: Worked as GA at the college of Applied Science and tech
pros: Great atmosphere, applied and acquired a wide range of skills. Helpful and cooperative manager. Worked part time 20 hours a week, flexible schedule.
cons: There were no cons for working part time. Was very satisfied during my time working as a grad assistant at the college of applied science and technology

review_title: Flex Hours & Fun Team But Double Standard and Difficult Customers
job_title: Usher, Cashier, Box Office Associate in Normal, IL
pros: great team dynamic, boss knows employees are students so very flexible scheduling, variety of shifts during day and evening, opportunities for other roles with the university
cons: limited hours, boss has double standard for male and female employees, handles Illinois Shakespeare Festival sales in addition to university sales which complicates things

job_title: Student Manager, Back of House in Normal, IL
pros: Great environment for college students. Able to gain skills in culinary, leadership and teamwork. Very flexible with your schedule for full-time students.
cons: Not a lot of interaction between Front of House & Back of House staff.

pros: Lots of opportunities for students to work, even if they're not the most desirable or applicable jobs. Flexible to student schedules.
cons: Illinois State University is currently in an unstable place with its budget because of Illinois politics. Getting at education or a job here may not be the best choice as of April 2016.

job_title: Sports Office Assistant in Normal, IL
pros: great benefits.  great hours with weekends off.  am able to get classes for free.  I enjoy the people i work with and being among a young crowd.
cons: the work is not challenging, no where to move up into, very political.  Every promotion or raise is based on schooling and not performance.

pros: Great people work in the top level positions who listen to the employees. Salary is competitive, and there is room for advancement.
cons: The area is truly a college town and the area is not diverse. The same applies to the employees of the university.

pros: Awesome work culture, excellent management and good support. There are many people who can support and help you when you join the company.
cons: There are not many cons, but the job responsibility is not very clear and you will probably do jobs that is not you forte, but you will learn a lot.

pros: Was given the necessary guidance to develop both professionally and personally.  Furthermore, the culture is great.
cons: The only con to working at Illinois State is the low pay.  I don't know if I would consider this a con because the cost of living in the area is relatively inexpensive.

pros: Flexibility on when the work could be done and the opportunity to work with different faculty members.
cons: I did not have any negative experiences, but I will point out that as a GA (research) you have to be good at multi-tasking and stay focused in order to be successful.

pros: Flexible hours and willing to work around schedules, they will provide more opportunities to work if you want to work
cons: Short shifts and will send you home early if there is nothing to do.  They also will just stop giving shifts part way through the year if they don't have work

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Normal, IL
pros: ISU has a great diverse working environment. The university cares about it grad students.
cons: ISU is located in the mid-west as such the school gets very cold in the winter and school is sometimes cancelled.

pros: Very flexible schedule, management is very accommodating to outside schedules, enjoyable atmosphere. Opportunities to get full time State positions sometimes.
cons: Politics of State run work environment can get in the way of things. Not for those who do not like to get dirty or sweaty, sometimes very grueling work.

job_title: Front End Developer in Normal, IL
pros: As a student, hours are often more loose than a traditional job, letting you work around your class schedule.  There were a lot of possibilities for learning and improving my skills.  I had practice working with others, and I had amazing mentors.
cons: Wish I would have applied sooner.

pros:
They gives you flexibility to manage your class timing with the current classes that your assisting.
They give you better opportunity to learn and teach at the same time so that you can master your skills.
cons: There are not such things like cons, but little more salary would be good.

pros: Working at Illinois state university as a graduate assistant enhanced my experience in tutoring undergraduate students and designing lab assignments.
cons: I cannot think of any downsides while working as a graduate assistant at Illinois State University. It was a good experience.
